"waynedickenson961 • Aug 16, 2013 12:52 AM Don, You can copy and paste from any link. 2. the ethics policy is legal or the policy would be removed by law. Don, your talking about represented collective bargaining rights to be free from intimidation, nothing more. The employee conduct is a employment at will doctrine. If a company no longer wants a man(VN) to be employed even with a labor contract they can be terminated without any reason Harry Stonecipher, a CEO of Boeing was terminated he had a employment contract better than you or I did . Don, he was representing Boeing and had a inside Boeing affair, no party was harmed . Yet Boeing decided to terminate his job. This guy your representing (VN) has violated company conduct policy while an active Boeing employee and can be terminated for any reason or no reason. As a retired, but experienced Labor Relations Manger for a very large top 10 prime contractor, I know the difference between a negotiated collective bargaining right and a company policy that can be enforced Don , you lose on this one. Wayne ."

A hater? Me? Are you kidding me? Go back and read a bunch of your own posts. Your intense and (probably) unjustified disdain for Boeing, its products, senior executives and management is off the friggin' charts. While I'd never claim to be an expert on Boeing's policies, procedures and rules, nor an expert on federal, state or local law, I'm very well acquainted with all of them. You clearly are not and made the mistake of engaging somebody who really does work for Boeing, designing commercial A/Ps and has done so not for years, but decades. I know what the hell I'm talking about as does Don Shuper, who's a retired Boeing engineer. Hopefully, you have learned something from this experience but I doubt it. When does it end? It ends when you stop lying to the people on this board and the public at large about the company for which I work and its products. There are plenty of factually accurate things about Boeing, its products, its executives and their decisions to be critical of and like many employees who have literally decades invested in this company I have been as critical as anybody but there's no need to make stuff up. Stop lying and I'll stop attacking you. Keep on lying however and I'm going to continue trying to set the record straight. It is a responsibility I have as a degreed engineer and like most engineers I take it pretty damn seriously.

Yes, I'm quite certain Boeing will be very concerned that I (and others) have revealed you to be a chronic liar. Record away you idiot. As Don Shuper (retired Boeing engineer who's very well versed in all things Boeing) told you, what I do on my own time, using my own equipment is none of Boeing's business. The only possible exception to that is if I were to violate a company policy or rule that extends beyond company property and I have committed no such offense. I'm an employee of the company. I'm not their slave and their reach does not extend into my personal life. Ever hear of something called defamation? How 'bout libel, which is defamation by written word or image? "Defamation—also called calumny, vilification, or traducement—is the communication of a false statement that harms the reputation of an individual, business, product, group, government, religion, or nation. Most jurisdictions allow legal action to deter various kinds of defamation and retaliate against groundless criticism." You'd better be careful. Yahoo! has a copy of every libelous post about Boeing you've ever made and you're skating on very thin ice.

Message.Title: Charleston 787 Production Lagging, Everett to Make Up the Difference
Message.Msg: Boeing's South Carolina facility is running behind projections and won't make its goal of producing three 787 Dreamliners a month by the end of 2013. In fact, the Everett plant will have to make up the difference in order for the company to reach its overall goal of 10 jetliners a month by year's end. As recently as July 24, when Boeing announced second-quarter earnings, Boeing CEO Jim McNerney insisted the company is on track to hit 10 Dreamliners monthly by the end of this year. But how Boeing accomplishes that has become more problematic. Company executives have started saying that Boeing’s North Charleston, S.C., plant is somewhat behind its goal of contributing three 787s monthly by the end of 2013. This was first reported in the Charleston Post and Courier, after a conversation between reporter Brendan Kearney and Boeing South Carolina executive Willy Geary. How's that right to work state working for you, Jim?

Topic.Title: Charleston 787 Production Lagging, Everett to Make Up the Difference

Message.Msg: From NYC787 site: Totally, Boeing has the ability to deliver 12 total this month but some of this depends on what shows up during the customer flights and if Charleston will able to start to deliver aircraft. Through all the 787 activity of the past few weeks, very little has come out of Charleston. Indeed, of the 9 787s that are complete (including one that is in Ft. Worth being painted) none of these airplanes have had a customer flight in preparation for delivery. The silence from Charleston has been deafening but it may not be entirely there fault. They are saddled with 6 787s that are to be delivered to three problem child airlines (Air India, China Southern and Hainan Airlines). The coming week should reveal more in terms of activity at Charleston.
